code.description: A medical code for the entity, taken from a controlled vocabulary or  ontology such as ICD-9, DiseasesDB, MeSH, SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, etc.

guideline.description: A medical guideline related to this entity.

study.description: A medical study or trial related to this entity.

typicalTest.description: A medical test typically performed given this condition.

riskFactor.description: A modifiable or non-modifiable factor that increases the risk of a patient  contracting this condition, e.g. age, coexisting condition.

subtype.description: A more specific type of the condition, where applicable, for example 'Type  1 Diabetes', 'Type 2 Diabetes', or 'Gestational Diabetes' for Diabetes.

possibleTreatment.description: A possible treatment to address this condition, sign or symptom.

possibleComplication.description: A possible unexpected and unfavorable evolution of a medical condition.  Complications may include worsening of the signs or symptoms of the  disease, extension of the condition to other organ systems, etc.

primaryPrevention.description: A preventative therapy used to prevent an initial occurrence of the medical  condition, such as vaccination.

secondaryPrevention.description: A preventative therapy used to prevent reoccurrence of the medical  condition after an initial episode of the condition.

description.description: A short description of the item.

signOrSymptom.description: A sign or symptom of this condition. Signs are objective or physically  observable manifestations of the medical condition while symptoms are the  subjective experience of the medical condition.

additionalType.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific  types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a  relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa  syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute  - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding  of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

image.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

cause.description: An underlying cause. More specifically, one of the causative agent(s) that  are most directly responsible for the pathophysiologic process that  eventually results in the occurrence.

pathophysiology.description: Changes in the normal mechanical, physical, and biochemical functions that  are associated with this activity or condition.

transmissionMethod.description: How the disease spreads, either as a route or vector, for example 'direct  contact', 'Aedes aegypti', etc.

relevantSpecialty.description: If applicable, a medical specialty in which this entity is relevant.

recognizingAuthority.description: If applicable, the organization that officially recognizes this entity as  part of its endorsed system of medicine.

mainEntityOfPage.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main  entity being described.  See background notes for details. Inverse property: mainEntity.

potentialAction.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which  this thing would play an 'object' role.

differentialDiagnosis.description: One of a set of differential diagnoses for the condition. Specifically, a  closely-related or competing diagnosis typically considered later in the  cognitive process whereby this medical condition is distinguished from  others most likely responsible for a similar collection of signs and  symptoms to reach the most parsimonious diagnosis or diagnoses in a patient.

infectiousAgent.description: The actual infectious agent, such as a specific bacterium.

associatedAnatomy.description: The anatomy of the underlying organ system or structures associated with  this entity.

epidemiology.description: The characteristics of associated patients, such as age, gender, race etc.

infectiousAgentClass.description: The class of infectious agent (bacteria, prion, etc.) that causes the  disease.

naturalProgression.description: The expected progression of the condition if it is not treated and allowed  to progress naturally.

expectedPrognosis.description: The likely outcome in either the short term or long term of the medical  condition.

stage.description: The stage of the condition, if applicable.

medicineSystem.description: The system of medicine that includes this MedicalEntity, for example  'evidence-based', 'homeopathic', 'chiropractic', etc.

sameAs.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's  identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or  official website.
